required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on February 08, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Understanding the Mental Health of Migrant Workers During the COVID-19 Outbreak
clinical_study.official_title: Understanding the Mental Health of Migrant Workers During the COVID-19 Outbreak

brief_summary.textblock: This study aims to understand the prevalence and predictors of psychological distress amongst migrant workers during the COVID-19 pandemic.

detailed_description.textblock:
Worldwide, there are an estimated 164 million migrant workers. Although studies have documented how migrant workers have an increased risk of adverse mental and physical health outcomes, little is known about their vulnerability during a health crisis.
In the current COVID-19 outbreak, nearly 30,000 migrant workers have been infected with SARS-CoV-2 in Singapore. This represents 9 in 10 of the local cases, and 25 dormitories have been gazetted to contain the spread of the virus. Correspondingly, these measures have placed a spotlight on the mental well-being of migrant workers.
In this research protocol, the investigators propose to administer a survey to understand the prevalence and predictors of psychological distress amongst migrant workers in Singapore. This will allow the investigators to capture the base rate of depression, anxiety, and stress symptoms in the population, and will also help to identify risk factors of psychological distress within this population.

primary_outcome.description: Depression, Anxiety and Stress Scale (DASS-21) is a validated 21-item measure that has been widely used during the current COVID-19 pandemic.

study_pop.textblock: Migrant workers who have or have not been diagnosed with COVID-19.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- 21 years, living in a dorm or EXPO/NUS Prince George Residences
Exclusion Criteria:
-
